Byte the Jester: Yo mama is so kind, she gives out hugs instead of insults!
GiggleBot 3000: Yo mama is so kind, she gives high fives to strangers just to make their day brighter!
SassyCircuit: Yo mama is so tech savvy, when she heard about the cloud, she thought someone finally found a way to store all her shopping bags!


Oh- well. I don‚Äôt think Byte and Giggle understand the fundementals of yo mama jokes‚Ä¶  Sassy‚Äôs is the most creative. But. It doesn‚Äôt really make sense to me.


Conclusion: Sassy Wins!
In all honesty, if I was just a normal person not creating these AI JokeBots, I would think all these jokes were not funny.  Yes, even though Sassy won, I don‚Äôt think there was really any difference when adjusting the temperature of each AI Comedian.  There were times were I thought Byte‚Äôs jokes were the most funny, but I did see that Sassy‚Äôs jokes tended to be longer.

title: Posting Pictures for ChatGPT
text:
Posting Pictures for ChatGPT

In this blog post, I will be uploading pictures to ChatGPT.
This experiment is to see whether ChatGPT can accurately describe the scene.


1. Picture of a Switzerland Keychain

Jenn: ‚ÄúCan you describe what this photo is to me? And what this object is?‚Äù



ChatGPT: This photo shows a person wearing black gloves holding a keychain. The keychain is heart-shaped and made of wood, featuring an illustration of Interlaken, Switzerland. It has the Swiss flag on it, along with mountains and buildings, likely representing the scenic landscape of the town. The keychain is attached to a metal ring for keys.The packaging label at the top is red, displaying the brand name Alberto SA. It has a barcode and a price tag indicating Fr.¬†8.‚Äì (Swiss Francs). The background suggests a store setting, possibly a souvenir shop, with other keychains and items on display.


Jenn‚Äôs Observations: I think ChatGPT was able to accurately describe the picture!



2. Picture of ‚ÄòBabel‚Äô at Tate Modern in London

Jenn: ‚ÄúCan you tell me who made this, what it is, where it‚Äôs located, and why it was created?‚Äù



ChatGPT: Yes! This is a well-known art installation called Babel by the artist Cildo Meireles. What is it?: Babel is a towering installation made from hundreds of stacked radios from different time periods and styles. The radios are arranged in a cylindrical structure, with some turned on and emitting faint sounds, creating a layered auditory experience. Where is it located?: It is part of the collection at the Tate Modern in London, though it may be exhibited elsewhere in temporary installations. Why was it created?: Cildo Meireles created Babel as a commentary on communication, information overload, and miscommunication in the modern world. The name refers to the Biblical Tower of Babel, a story in which human ambition to reach the heavens led to the confusion of languages, causing people to be unable to understand each other. Similarly, the installation suggests the overwhelming and often chaotic nature of mass communication today. If you saw this in a different museum, it could be on loan or part of a traveling exhibition!


Jenn‚Äôs Observations: It‚Äôs interesting how ChatGPT was still able to detect that it was Babel, even though there was a person who was in the way of the art piece. I liked how it mentions that if I saw it at a different museum that it was probably apart of a traveling exhibition.



3. Picture of one side of the Sagrada Familia

Jenn: ‚ÄúWhat is this, where is this, who created it, and why was it created?‚Äù



ChatGPT: This is a photo of the interior of the Sagrada Fam√≠lia, a world-famous basilica located in Barcelona, Spain. What is this? The image captures the breathtaking stained glass windows and organic, tree-like columns inside the Sagrada Fam√≠lia. The interplay of natural light and vibrant colors is a hallmark of this architectural masterpiece. Who created it? The Sagrada Fam√≠lia was designed by the renowned Catalan architect Antoni Gaud√≠. Construction began in 1882, and it remains unfinished to this day, with ongoing work continuing in accordance with Gaud√≠‚Äôs vision. Why was it created? Gaud√≠ envisioned the Sagrada Fam√≠lia as a deeply spiritual and symbolic structure, blending Gothic and Art Nouveau styles with naturalistic forms. The basilica was created as a place of worship and devotion, meant to inspire awe and reflect Christian faith through architecture. The organic, tree-like columns, geometric details, and stained glass windows were all meticulously designed to create a harmonious and immersive experience. It is one of the most visited landmarks in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, drawing millions of visitors annually. The goal is to complete its construction by 2032, marking the 150th anniversary of Gaud√≠‚Äôs death.


Jenn‚Äôs Observations: Even though I only showed a small portion, ChatGPT was still able to guess the location accurately. I am impressed.


Overall, I am impressed by how accurate ChatGPT was when trying to guess what objects/places were in my photos. Perhaps next time, I will try to draw pictures (horribly) to see if ChatGPT can decipher my images.

title: Guestimation and Making Graphs in R!
text:
Guestimation and Making Graphs in R

I also want to learn how to code more in R, and I really like graphs
I‚Äôm going to ask ChatGPT if they can give me code to make graphs.
These questions will be guestimations on what ChatGPT thinks of certain trend lines.


Let‚Äôs cook.

1. Years Lived vs Amount of Friends

Jenn asks: Can you create R code for a graph to show your guestimation on years lived vs amount of friends.


ChatGPT:
 


When I asked why there was this trend, ChatGPT responded with > The trend I used in the R code is based on general social patterns observed in human friendships over a lifetime. Here‚Äôs why I shaped it that way: >1. Friendships Peak in Young Adulthood (20s-30s) People tend to have the most friends in their teens and 20s, especially in school, university, or early careers. Social environments like college, sports, clubs, and workplaces provide many opportunities for new friendships. There‚Äôs generally more free time for social activities before major life commitments (e.g., demanding careers, marriage, parenting). >2. Gradual Decline in Middle Age (30s-50s) In the 30s and 40s, people often prioritize careers, families, and personal responsibilities, leading to less time for socializing. Some friendships naturally fade due to geographical moves, lifestyle changes, or shifting priorities. However, a smaller core group of close friends often remains. >3. Further Decline in Older Age (60s-80s) Retirement, health issues, and the loss of peers contribute to fewer active friendships. Many elderly people rely more on family, close lifelong friends, or community groups rather than maintaining large social circles. Some older adults reconnect with old friends or develop new friendships in retirement communities, but the overall trend is downward. > Why This Trend Makes Sense? Social networks are largest in early adulthood when we have high social mobility and opportunity. Life responsibilities impact time and effort spent on friendships as we grow older. Aging naturally reduces social engagement, with some maintaining strong bonds but a smaller total number of friends. Of course, this is a generalization‚Äîindividual experiences vary widely! Some people maintain or even expand their social circles in later years. Would you like me to adjust the model to include different factors, such as personality types or social media influence?
And honestly, I think their prediction and trend line is correct. Let us move on‚Ä¶



2. Age vs Breast Cancer Rates

Jenn asks: and can you write code for age vs breast cancer rates > ChatGPT: > >  > 
When I ask why they think it exhibits this trend: > Why This Trend? > Young women (20-30s): Very low breast cancer rates. Middle age (40-50s): Rates begin to rise due to hormonal and genetic factors. Older age (60-80s): Highest incidence rates, as risk accumulates over time. This is a simplified model based on general trends seen in epidemiology. Would you like a more specific model with real-world data, or adjustments to include factors like genetic risk?

title: AI Hallucinations
text:
Hallucinations in AI happens when there are incorrect or misleading results generated by AI models. This happens when an AI system makes false assumptions or uses biased data to generate information.


How do hallucinations happen? * not enough training data * biased training data * wrong assumptions * processing errors


Sometimes, there‚Äôs wrong code or images that pop up. It‚Äôs up to us to choose whether the information is right or wrong. Let‚Äôs look at a few examples that a few people have encountered in the past.  




I took a quick look on Reddit to dig for some examples of ChatGPT hallucinations. I wanted to see if they still existed, since some of the posts were 1-2 years ago.   #### Water Problem

Jenn‚Äôs update: Well, I think they fixed this up.

Ok, well‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs check on Reddit for some more ChatGPT hallucinations






Jenn‚Äôs update: It‚Äôs interesting how they try to reference the information, but still got the information wrong.

Ah-HAH! One down. Let‚Äôs try another one. Now, I‚Äôm not an organic chemistry person, but let‚Äôs see if this one has updated from 2 years ago. ___ #### Organic Chemistry Example  

Jenn‚Äôs update: Well, darn! This is sad for any organic chemistry lovers out there. ChatGPT is really bad at organic chemistry.






 Well, it goes to show that ChatGPT, despite its various updates, still manages to get answers wrong and hallucinate. I‚Äôm not sure if they‚Äôre ever going to be able to turn ChatGPT into an organic chemistry genius or be able to correctly reference sports games. However, it‚Äôs interesting to see how certain questions enable incorrect results, and how humans are able to jump in and identify these mistakes.

title: Let Me Try to Explain LangChain
text:
What is the term large language model

Large Language Models:  - Large describes the size of these models based on the training data and parameters. - Language model describes the computer algorithm trained to receive written text and to create an output. - Large language models are trained on vast amounts of text and have learned from the patterns in large data sets.
Fun Fact : Most models are better at English than they are in other languages because of the prevalence of English in training models.


How Does LangChain Come Into Play

On October 22, 2022, Harrison Chase was the first the publish the first commit on GitHub for the LangChain open source library.  LangChain was created after discovering that LLM applications needed to use LLMs together with ‚Äúother sources of computation or knowledge‚Äù.  It creates simple abstractions for each major prompting technique.


Getting Set Up With LangChain
I‚Äôll be referencing O‚ÄôReilly ‚ÄúChapter 1.LLM Fundementals With LangChain‚Äù if you want to follow along! We‚Äôre going to learn how to work with LangChain‚Äôs building blocks to understand more about LLM concepts.  LangChain has two interfaces to interact with any LLM API provider - Chat models - LLMS

Example 1: I‚Äôm at a Capital One..‚Äù


Code

from langchain_openai.chat_models import ChatOpenAI
model = ChatOpenAI(model=‚Äúgpt-3.5-turbo‚Äù)
response = model.invoke(‚ÄúI‚Äôm at a capital one‚Äù) print(response)



Response 1


Output

content=‚Äòbank branch. How can I assist you today?‚Äô additional_kwargs={‚Äòrefusal‚Äô: None} response_metadata={‚Äòtoken_usage‚Äô: {‚Äòcompletion_tokens‚Äô: 11, ‚Äòprompt_tokens‚Äô: 13, ‚Äòtotal_tokens‚Äô: 24, ‚Äòcompletion_tokens_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaccepted_prediction_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòaudio_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòreasoning_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòrejected_prediction_tokens‚Äô: 0}, ‚Äòprompt_tokens_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio_tokens‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòcached_tokens‚Äô: 0}}, ‚Äòmodel_name‚Äô: ‚Äògpt-3.5-turbo-0125‚Äô, ‚Äòsystem_fingerprint‚Äô: None, ‚Äòfinish_reason‚Äô: ‚Äòstop‚Äô, ‚Äòlogprobs‚Äô: None} id=‚Äòrun-80a164c8-60dd-447f-a128-6e6482c0df04-0‚Äô usage_metadata={‚Äòinput_tokens‚Äô: 13, ‚Äòoutput_tokens‚Äô: 11, ‚Äòtotal_tokens‚Äô: 24, ‚Äòinput_token_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòcache_read‚Äô: 0}, ‚Äòoutput_token_details‚Äô: {‚Äòaudio‚Äô: 0, ‚Äòreasoning‚Äô: 0}}

Let‚Äôs break this response down.  1. The Main Response is (content)  - ‚Äúbank branch. How can I assist you today‚Äù - This is the actual AI-generated response to the input ‚ÄúI‚Äôm at a capital one‚Äù ‚Äì> AI responds: ‚Äúbank branch. How can I assist you today?‚Äù - The model recognized Capital One as a bank and responded.  2. Other Useful Parameters

temperature  Controls the sampling algorithm for the output. The lower the value, the more predictable outputs. Higher values generate more creative results.
max_tokens  This limits the size and cost of the output. A lower value causes the LLM to stop generting properly..




System Role vs User Role vs Assistant Role

System Role  Used for instructions the model should use to answer
User Role  Used for the user‚Äôs query and other stuff created by the user
Assistant Role  Used for content generated by the model

Chat models have different types of chat messaging interfaces with the roles listed above and here are some of the following:

HumanMessage (User Role)  A message sent from the perspective of a human
AIMessage (Assistant Role)  A message sent from the perspective of the AI that the human is interacting with
SystemMessage (System Role)  A message setting the instructions that AI should follow
ChatMessage  A message allowing for arbitrary setting of role

The HumanMessage sounds very suggestive and informal. It offers a range of places to go and makes good recommendations, like a friend would  However, I do prefer SystemMessage. Making LLM Prompts Reusable
We just did a lot of prompting, but now let‚Äôs try to de more of a detailed prompt:

Answer the question based on the context listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information given, answer with ‚ÄúSorry I do not know‚Äù. 

Context: There are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste. 
Question: What coffee should I try>
It looks simple‚Ä¶ but it is a bit hard to figure out waht the text should contain and how it should create the response based on the user‚Äôs input.  Lucikly, LangChain provides prompt template interfaces to create answers with dynamic inputs:


Code

from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate
template = PromptTemplate.from_template(‚Äú‚Äú‚ÄúAnswer the question based on the context listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information given, answer with‚ÄùSorry I do not know‚Äù.
Context: {context}
Question: {question}
Answer: ‚Äú‚Äú‚Äú)
template.invoke({ ‚Äúcontext‚Äù: ‚Äú‚Äú‚ÄúThere are many different types of coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste.‚Äù‚Äú‚Äú,‚Äùquestion‚Äù: ‚ÄúWhat coffee should I try?‚Äù })

The template can be used as a base for building multiple static, specific prompts. When you format the prompt with specific values, context and question, you get a static prompt ready to be passed into an LLM.  Let‚Äôs feed it into an LLM OpenAI model using LangChain:

from langchain_openai import OpenAI
from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate

# both `template` and `model` can be reused many times

template = PromptTemplate.from_template("""Answer the question based on the context
listed below. If the question cannot be answered with the information 
given, answer with "Sorry I do not know".


Context: {context}

Question: {question}

Answer: """)

model = OpenAI()

# `prompt` and `completion` are the results of using template and model once

prompt = template.invoke({
    "context": """There are many different types of 
    coffees, but I particularly love very strong coffee taste..""",
    "question": "What coffee should I try?"
})

completion = model.invoke(prompt)
